case_vignette: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician for a 3-month history of fatigue. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He had a transient ischemic attack 3 years ago. He drinks 3 beers a day, and sometimes a couple more on social occasions. He currently takes aspirin, simvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, and metoprolol. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation on room air is 97%. He is in no distress but shows marked pallor and has multiple pinpoint, red, nonblanching spots on his extremities. On palpation, his spleen is significantly enlarged. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin of 8.0 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 80,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 34,000/mm3. A blood smear shows immature cells with large, prominent nucleoli and pink, elongated, needle-shaped cytoplasmic inclusions.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been feeling very tired for the past three months.
Have you noticed any unexplained weight loss during this time?
No, I haven't noticed any unexplained weight loss.

Do you have a history of anemia or frequent infections?

[Anemia: A condition in which the body does not have enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to body tissues. Frequent infections: Frequent infections can be a sign of a weakened immune system, which can be a symptom of certain cancers.]

Final Diagnosis: Anemia (if symptoms of anemia persist after addressing potential causes such as iron deficiency, further testing may be necessary to rule out other causes such as cancer or chronic disease)

[If the patient reports symptoms of frequent infections, further questioning and testing may be necessary to rule out a potential underlying cancer.]
